description.narrative: By 2020, communities living in targeted areas have a better understanding of the benefits of good hygiene practices, particularly the use of toilets, the consumption of quality water and the practice of hand washing with soap.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2020, communities living in targeted areas have a better understanding of the benefits of good hygiene practices, particularly the use of toilets, the consumption of quality water and the practice of hand washing with soap.

description.narrative:
Twenty seven new communities with over 16,900 people were triggered to end the practice of open defecation through the involvement of 302 local actors and “natural leaders”; over 5,700 students from 19 schools were given the opportunity to learn the benefits of key hygiene practices through the implementation of the “3-star approach” for WASH in school; and 240,000 vulnerable families benefited from the awareness raising interventions on key basic practices related to water treatment and storage with access facilitated to water treatment product.
| Status:On-track | As-of Date:09/02/2020

title.narrative: Number of men and women who gained access to safely managed sanitation services in the reporting year only, as a result of UNICEF direct support
Number of communities certified free of open defecation that integrate standards for protection of girls and women as a result of UNICEF and partner support (leveraged/indirect)
% of people who know the good hygienic practices (key moments of handwashing) in target areas
Number of additional people living in the newly certified Open Defecation Free (ODF) communities as a result of UNICEF CATS programming during the year of reporting
% of people who have access to drinking water through household water treatment in target areas
